Process for the management of internal reviews .................................................... 7
Introduction

Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust (the Trust) aims to improve health and wellbeing through excellent, financially sustainable services, provided by staff supported to develop, innovate and build rewarding careers.

A well led organisation will ensure that there is effective participation in and learning from internal and external reviews and that learning is shared effectively and used to make improvements (CQC 2019).

The purpose of an internal review programme is to ensure that we are providing a safe and high quality experience for every service user. An internal review is a good opportunity to check that we are maintaining high standards and providing high quality and safe care every day. It also helps to highlight areas requiring improvement ensuring that these are recognised and the opportunity to improve the quality of services is harnessed.
Scope

This policy and procedure has been developed to ensure that there are robust arrangements in place and a co-ordinated and consistent approach to internal compliance reviews, with the aim of supporting and fostering a culture of continuous improvement.
This policy and procedure will:
Provide a robust framework for conducting internal reviews
Support continuous improvement in response to a review
Provide a governance framework for the outcome of internal reviews, ensuring a quality improvement approach is adopted
Ensure that there is a central register of all internal reviews
Provide assurance to the Board via the Quality Governance Committee on the progress against the internal compliance review programme

This procedure covers any internal review carried out in accordance with the CQC key lines of enquiry. It does not cover other performance management, accountability and governance arrangements and does not cover external agency reviews. Refer to the Policy for the Management of external agency reviews, inspections and accreditations.
Definitions

table_items.text: Any formal review of services carried out internally as part of the quality improvement framework using the CQC key lines of enquiry.

Internal systems and processes which regulate and assure the activities and operation of the Trust, which identify non conformities or variation from the accepted standard to practice. Non-compliance is escalated to the appropriate person/s or relevant group or committee.
Relates to action planning. The actions are Specific, Measurable, Achievable, Reaslistic/Relevant and Timebound.

data.text: Roles and responsibilities within the Trust
The Governance structure for the reporting of internal reviews can be seen in appendix
Trust Board is responsible for ensuring that:
the trust has a robust improvement strategy in response to internal reviews
Quality Governance Sub-Committees is responsible for:
Overseeing plans for internal compliance reviews.
Providing assurance to the Trust Board by exception reporting.
Risk and Compliance Group will:
Receive progress reports on the internal review programmes including a summary on the findings, recommendations and improvement plans.
Reviewing recommendations and subsequent improvement plans following internal reviews.
Divisional / Departmental Governance Groups are responsible for:
Reviewing the recommendations arising from internal reviews and ensuring that these are including in quality improvement plans and programmes.
Reviewing any improvement plans and considering whether the identified actions and timescales for implementation are appropriate and adequate.
Consider the risks associated with any non-compliance and ensure these are escalated to the appropriate Senior Manager and recorded on the appropriate risk register.
Where a specific committee/ group is not identified, the nominated group will be the relevant division/ department governance meeting.
Clinical Directors and Heads of Nursing / Associate Heads of Nursing are responsible for:
Providing information requested as part of an internal review
Ensuring that recommendations arising from internal reviews are considered and including in quality improvement plans and programmes
Ensuring that there are robust mechanisms in place to monitor the implementation of an improvements arising from internal reviews.
Appropriate risk assessments are carried out for issues of concern highlighted through internal reviews.
Associate Director for Risk and Compliance is responsible for:
Ensuring there is an internal review framework and process in place.
Developing and delivering the internal review programme.
Identifying relevant individuals to be part of site visits.
Risk and Compliance Team is responsible for:

Supporting the delivery of the internal review programme including obtaining and reviewing data and information, organising and participating in site visits, producing reports and obtaining information in relation to the improvements from divisions
Ensuring the review teams are fully briefed in advance of any site visits and aware of their responsibilities and adherence to trust policies and procedures
Maintaining an up to date register of internal reviews and outcomes
Provide monthly updates on internal reviews to the Risk and Compliance
Group.
Review Teams are responsible for:
Familiarising themselves with the review process and standards.
Ensuring they adhere to trust policies and procedures whilst conducting site visits.
Maintaining staff and patient confidentiality at all times.
Fostering a supportive approach and encouraging improvement.
All members of staff are responsible for:
Participating in the internal review process, ensuring that any information is provided in a timely manner when requested.
Engaging in the process, ensuring an open and honest approach.
Supporting the quality improvement process in relation to internal review findings.
Programme of internal reviews
The programme of internal reviews will be developed in advance using a risk based approach to prioritise the areas for review.

The reviews will be aligned to the CQC core services and each core service will receive a minimum of one review per year. It should be noted that the core services are not aligned to the trust organisational structure and each core service review may span a number of care groups, divisions and sites. The core service descriptions can be seen in appendix 2
Risk profile preparation and selection of areas for review
6.3.1 A risk profile will be used to determine the prioritisation of core service reviews. This will be based on the information gathered from the following areas;
Previous CQC ratings including requirement notices, warning notices or conditions
CQC insight report ratings
Never events and serious incidents
High impact concerns or recommendations highlighted from peer reviews, external inspections or accreditations

6.3.2 The risk profile will be updated on a monthly basis and used to inform whether any changes are required with the internal review programme. Any changes to the programme will be discussed and agreed in advance with the Director for Governance and Chief Nursing Officer. The updated programme will be presented to the Risk and Compliance Group for information.
Process for the management of internal reviews
The flowchart in appendix 3 acts as a guide for the operational management of internal reviews including the governance process.
CQC domains
The review will focus around the five key questions (domains) that the CQC ask. Are services:
SAFE – people are protected from abuse and avoidable harm
EFFECTIVE – people's care, treatment and support achieves good outcomes, promotes a good quality of life and is based on the best available evidence
CARING – staff involve and treat people with compassion, kindness, dignity and respect
RESPONSIVE – services are well organised so that they meet people's needs
WELL-LED – leadership, management and governance of the organisation assures the delivery of high quality, person-centred care, supports learning and innovation, and promotes an open and fair culture
Information gathering
6.4.1  Information will be gathered as part of the internal review and will be used to highlight areas for improvement. Information will be obtained from the following areas as a minimum.
Statutory and mandatory training rates;
IPC audit results;
Staffing vacancies;
Record keeping audit results;
Medication storage audit results;
Serious incidents numbers / never events;
DoC compliance;
Response to external reviews;
Nursing audit results – nutrition, hydration and pain;
Mortality outliers;
Readmission rates;
Response to national clinical audits;
Appraisal rates;
Consent audit results;
MCA and DOLs training compliance;
Friends and family response rates and scores;
Complaint response times;
Risk register;
Information Governance audit results.
6.1.2  In addition to the minimum information described above, additional evidence may be gathered according to the CQC Core Service Frameworks.
Site visits

6.5.1 Site visits may need to be conducted as part of the review, however where possible previous information will be sourced to inform the review such as Infection Prevention and Control Visits. Where this is not possible, a team will be convened to visit each area.
6.5.2 Review team
6.5.3 Where it is determined that a site visit is required, a team will be conveyed and ideally will include representation from the following areas and specialities:
Infection prevention and control;
Pharmacy;
Nursing / midwifery;
Governance.

6.5.4 The review team should consist of no more than 5 individuals and ideally where possible should include external representation (such as from the Acute Commissioning Team or other providers) and where possible should include a peer reviewer (i.e. representation from another site or ward but from a similar speciality). The review team should where possible include staff with knowledge and skills in the areas being visited (for example a registered midwife should be present for all reviews of maternity services).

6.5.5 The aim of the review is to be supportive to staff and the organisation in order to improve and learn. All members of the review team will be briefed in advance of conducting a site visit to ensure they are aware of the expectations of their role, the standards of conduct and behaviour in relation to the visit and adherence to trust policies and procedures. The information provided to the review team can be seen in appendix 4.
Feedback from internal reviews

7.1.1 Following a site visit, the review team will meet to review the information gathered and determine any points for immediate feedback. Feedback should be provided to the person in charge at the end of the visit and should include areas of good and outstanding practice, any immediate actions required and any key areas for improvement.
7.1.2 The verbal feedback will be followed up with an email to the ward / department confirming the key highlights along with a brief summary of the findings
A draft core service report will be produced taking into consideration the information gathered and the site visit findings.

The draft report will be provided within 10 working days of the final site visit, or in the case where no site visits took place, within 10 working days of the expected date of the visit. The draft report will be sent to the relevant senior individuals within each Division and Care Group including ward / departmental managers, matrons, Associate  Directors of  Nursing  /  Heads  of  Nursing  /  Midwifery,  Clinical  Leads, Clinical Directors, Directors of Nursing and Medical Directors.
Any comments regarding factual accuracy should be returned within 5 working days to the Risk and Compliance Team and the final report will then be circulated within 20 working days of the review.
Reviewing and reporting on recommendations

Care Groups, Divisions and wards / departments are responsible for considering the findings of the internal review report and incorporating any recommendations into relevant quality improvement plans and programmes.

The final internal review report will be presented to the subsequent Risk and Compliance Group and Divisions are expected to include any recommendations and actions arising from the review within their Risk and Compliance exception reports.

Where an action plan is required following a review, the trust standard action plan template should be used (see appendix 5). Divisions and Care Groups are responsible for monitoring progress with any actions. Actions should normally be completed within 3 months of the review and where this is not possible, consideration should be given to adding this to the divisional risk register.
Information governance
Confidentiality must be maintained for any information / evidence gathered as part of the review.
If the information/evidence contains patient identifiable information / person identifiable data (PID) this will be removed before including in the reports.

The confidentiality of staff will be maintained and every effort will be made to ensure that staff are not identified within the report. An exception to this is where the feedback is positive (e.g “staff said that the ward manager had made a big improvement and was approachable”)
Monitoring of actions

Each Division is responsible for monitoring any actions or quality improvement plans developed in response to an internal review. The purpose of the review is to be supportive, enabling Divisions and Care Groups to identify where improvements are required and providing a learning environment for these to be incorporated into quality improvement programmes.
Training requirements
There are no specific training requirements, however staff can receive advice and support with any aspect of this procedure from the Governance, Risk and Compliance Team.

Appendix 2: Core service descriptions

Urgent and emergency Care – refers to the service that people can access, without a referral, in an urgent or emergency situation. Services include emergency departments, urgent care centres (UCCs), clinical decision unit, ambulatory care unit, minor injury unit and walk-in centres.

Medical Care (including older people's care) - in general terms, medical care includes those services that involve assessment, diagnosis and treatment of adults by medical interventions rather than suery. Medical care also includes endoscopy services, acute assessment units (medical assessment units), general wards, specialty wards, including gerontology (also known as care of the elderly) wards.

Surgery - This core service involves most surgical activity in the hospital. It icludes planned (elective) surgery, day case surgery and emergency surgery. Areas included are pre-assessment areas, theatres, anaesthetic rooms and recovery areas and surgical wards. Disciplines include trauma and orthopaedics (T&O), colorectal surgery, general surgery, urology, ear, nose and throat (ENT), cardiac surgery, vascular surgery, ophthalmic surgery, neurosurgery, breast surgery, upper gastro-intestinal surgery, plastics and maxillofacial surgery, thoracic surgery and interventional radiology.

Critical Care - This includes areas where patients receive more intensive monitoring and treatment for life-threatening conditions. These areas are usually described as high dependency units (level 2), intensive care units (level 3) or by the umbrella term, critical care units and includes units for specific conditions such as renal or respiratory failure only if they are funded as a high dependency unit and or are led by a consultant intensivist. Critical care also includes outreach services provided in other areas of a hospital.

Maternity - This includes all services for women that relate to pregnancy. It includes ante and post-natal services, as well as labour wards, birth centres or units and theatres providing obstetric related surgery. New born babies requiring treatment in a neonatal unit comes under the core service for children and young people.

Services for children and young people - This includes all services for children up to the age of 18 and includes inpatient wards, outpatients, end of life care, all paediatric surgery, the interface with maternity and community services, paediatric intensive care units, arrangements for transition to adult services. It does not include care provided in the emergency department, as this is covered under the urgent and emergency core service.

End of life care - End of life care involves all care for patients who are approaching the end of their life and following death. A trust may deliver care on any ward or as part of any of its services. It includes aspects of basic nursing care, specialist palliative care, bereavement support and mortuary services.
The definition of end of life includes patients who are ‘approaching the end of life'

when they are likely to die within the next 12 months. This includes patients whose death is imminent (expected within a few hours or days) and those with advanced, progressive, incurable conditions, general frailty and co-existing conditions that mean they are expected to die within 12 months, existing conditions that put them at risk of dying if there is a sudden acute crisis in that condition and life-threatening acute conditions caused by sudden catastrophic events. Stillbirths come under the maternity core service, end of life care that relates to terminations of pregnancy and miscarriages come under the gynaecology service and end of life care services that relate to children and young people come under the core service for children and young people.

Outpatients - Outpatient services include all areas where people receive advice or care and treatment without being admitted as an inpatient or day case. It does not include children's outpatient services, as these are covered under the children and young people service.

Gynaecology and termination of pregnancy - for gynaecology this includes all services provided to women that relate to gynaecology. This includes providing advice and treatment to women requiring a wide range of both general and specialist care throughout their lives, from birth until after menopause. Services can include paediatric gynaecology, acute pain, pre-menstrual problems, fertility, bladder dysfunction, colposcopy, menopause and oncology. Termination of pregnancy is also included within the scope of this additional service.

Diagnostic Imaging - this service includes all areas where people undergo physiological measurements and diagnostic testing, receive diagnostic test results. Diagnostic imaging includes imaging services and screening procedures, such as X-rays, fluoroscopy, MRIs, PET, CT and DEXA scans, ultrasound (including baby ultrasound that is not part of a maternity service), nuclear medicine scans, and mammography.
It does not include interventional radiology, theatre radiology and cardiac catheterisation imaging as these are included in the surgery core service.

data.text: Appendix 4 – Briefing for review team
Thank you for supporting Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust with this CQC style internal review.

The aim of the internal review is to compare our services against the CQC Key lines of enquiry (KLOEs), to identify areas of good and outstanding practice and to identify areas where we need to improve to ensure we can provide safe care for our patients.
The purpose of this briefing is to provide you with the information you need in order to assist in the review process and will outline the following;
Expectations of your role on the review team
Explain the review process, the assessment ratings and what ‘good' looks like
Provide information about the key lines of enquiry and prompts
Detail the programme and areas to be visited
Explain the review tools and templates to be used
Your role on the review team

The aim of the review is to be supportive to staff and the organisation in order to improve and learn. It is therefore important that certain behaviours and attitudes are adopted to ensure an effective outcome.

Please ensure you wear your ID badge at all times and introduce yourself to the ward / department manager. When speaking with staff, patients or visitors, explain the purpose of your discussion and that we are looking at the quality of services.

Adopt ‘bare below the elbows' standards and ensure that you use the alcohol gels on entrance and exit to all clinical areas. Remove wristwatches, bracelets and roll up your sleeves. Face masks must also be worn whilst on trust premises.
Please remember that the primary focus of staff is on their clinical duties and therefore if they are too busy or cannot be interrupted at that time, offer to come back at a later stage.
The templates and forms are there as a guide only and you should also refer to the KLOEs during the review.

You should take clear and accurate notes of any discussions or observations and ensure that these have been written or typed up and left with the lead reviewer before you leave. All discussions with staff, patients or visitors should be written in such a way that individuals cannot be identified. At the end of the site visit it is the responsibility of the lead reviewer to ensure that the notes have been submitted to the Risk and Compliance Team.

If at any point during the review there is an issue that needs to be escalated, please report this to the person in charge of the ward or department or to your lead reviewer. Issues requiring immediate escalation may include a patient who is immediate danger or unsafe practices which may put staff or patients in danger. Most issues can be escalated as part of the team feedback.

If you are unable to answer any questions by staff, patients or visitors, tell them that you will find out and that someone will get back to them. Take their details and speak to your lead reviewer who will be able to advise on next steps.
The review process
CQC Domains
The review will focus around five key questions (domains) that the CQC ask. Are services:
SAFE – people are protected from abuse and avoidable harm
EFFECTIVE – people's care, treatment and support achieves good outcomes, promotes a good quality of life and is based on the best available evidence
CARING – staff involve and treat people with compassion, kindness, dignity and respect
RESPONSIVE – services are well organised so that they meet people's needs
WELL-LED – leadership, management and governance of the organisation assures the delivery of high quality, person-centred care, supports learning and innovation, and promotes an open and fair culture
Key lines of enquiry (KLOEs)

The KLOE help to answer the five key questions and provide consistency in what and how we review services. The teams will be asked to use the KLOEs to ensure that the review is focused in the right areas and provides information and evidence about each service being reviewed. It is not expected that every KLOE will be reviewed but it is important to focus on those that are important based on the evidence about each area and service that has been gathered. A full description of the KLOEs are provided in the pack for each team and should be read to ensure a full understanding of what is being looked at.
